title: 115_hr5369
content: The "Earmark Elimination Act of 2018" prohibits the consideration of legislation containing earmarks. The "Earmark Elimination Act of 2018" prohibits the consideration of any bill, joint resolution, amendment, or conference report in the House of Representatives if it includes a congressional earmark, limited tax benefit, or limited tariff benefit. If a point of order is raised and sustained, the earmark or benefit will be removed from the measure. The "Earmark Elimination Act of 2018" prohibits considering bills with earmarks, tax benefits, or tariff benefits in the House. If a point of order is sustained, the earmark or benefit will be removed from the measure. If a point of order is raised and sustained with respect to a conference report or motion, it will be considered rejected, and the remaining disagreement will be resolved accordingly. The House must decide whether to recede and concur in Senate amendments or insist further on House amendments after sustaining points of order. The House has privileged motions to consider Senate amendments, including receding and concurring with an amendment, requesting further conference, or insisting on disagreement. If a point of order is raised regarding congressional earmarks or tax benefits, the Chair will determine the provision's status. The House has privileged motions to consider Senate amendments, including receding and concurring with an amendment, requesting further conference, or insisting on disagreement. If a point of order is raised regarding congressional earmarks or tax benefits, the Chair will determine the provision's status. A congressional earmark, limited tax benefit, or limited tariff benefit will be decided without debate or intervening motion. Rule XXI of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended by striking clause 9. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk defines "congressional earmark" as a provision requesting specific budget authority for a contract or expenditure, and "limited tax benefit" as a tax provision benefiting 10 or fewer entities. The curr_chunk defines "limited tariff benefit" as a provision in the Harmonized Tariff Schedule benefiting 10 or fewer entities.
